purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 may be used for the definition of any electromechanical product in most industries, and it supports different levels of product complexity, from very simple to very complex products.
purpose.note: For the automotive industry and ground transportation, the scope of this part of ISO 10303 covers cars, trucks, buses, and motorcycles. It applies also to other forms of vehicles, such as rail, agricultural, and construction vehicles.
For the aerospace and defense industry, the scope of this part of ISO 10303 covers fixed and rotary wing aircraft, satellites, weapon systems, engines and other systems.
It applies also to other industries, such as ship building, consumer products.

imp_meth.description:
For various reasons, some entities may not be completely exported into an exchange structure. There may be mandatory information in the MIM that has no correspondence in the ARM. Sometimes an application may not maintain all the information that is anticipated for the data exchange. Other times, the information may be maintained by a sending system but not included in the data exchange. Nevertheless, the preprocessor must provide values for all mandatory attributes in an exchange file.
When no data is provided by a sending system for a string value, the preprocessor shall use '/NULL' or the empty string ''.
To further indicate the reason why no data is provided, the following convention shall be used:
empty string '' indicates user data managed by the sending system but not provided for data exchange;
string '/NULL' indicates user data in a mandatory attribute that is not managed by the sending system or currently not known or a mandatory MIM information that has no correspondence in the ARM;
$ is used in the physical part 21 file, if an optional attribute is not instantiated.
In general, the empty null string '' or the default string '/NULL' shall not be used as valid user data.
In case a mandatory MIM instance has no ARM correspondence through the mapping and no useful values can be provided the MIM instance shall be created with minimal 'dummy' information:
Empty string '' or string '/NULL' for all mandatory string type attributes with the same distinction as defined above;
Omission of all optional attributes ($ in the physical file). This rule applies recursively to further mandatory referenced instances in the AIM.
The following cases give examples for such required '' 'dummy' MIM instances:
ARM object: Project maps to MIM element: organizational_project, mandatory MIM reference is organizational_project.responsible_organizations S[1:?] to organization, 'dummy' MIM instance is organization with organization.name = '/NULL'.
ARM object Product_class maps to MIM element product_concept, mandatory MIM reference is product_concept.market_context to product_concept_context, 'dummy' MIM instances are: product_concept_context with product_concept_context.market_segment_type = '/NULL' and application_context_element.name = '/NULL' (inherited mandatory attribute), application_context with application_context.application = '/NULL'
This part of ISO 10303 uses 2 implementation methods for data exchange and integration:
MIM schema based ISO 10303-21 file format;
Domain Model XML schema based XML file format derived from the Domain Model SysML.
The latter method is recommended for applications in the scope of product data management, process planning, composite design, and kinematics. For mechanical design applications in the scope of geometry models including shape representation, presentation, surface conditions, dimension and geometric tolerance data, annotated 3D models, and drawings, the ISO 10303-21 file format based implementation method shall be used.
For legacy reasons, the MIM schema based ISO 10303-21 file format may also be used for applications in the scope of product data management, process planning, composite design, and kinematics.
For the interoperations of the 2 implementation forms in the same application area, mappings are defined. The mapping is defined in several steps:
The mapping from SysML Domain Model schema to the SysML ARM schema is defined in clause 4.5 of ISO/TS 10303-4442.
The mapping from the ARM EXPRESS schema to the MIM EXPRESS schema is defined in ISO/TS 10303-442. Product structure data contained in a MIM schema based ISO 10303-21 file can be translated into product structure data conform to the Domain Model XML schema.
Domain Model XML files and MIM schema based ISO 10303-21 files can be used together in mixed scenarios. Product structure defined as Domain Model XML file and geometry data defined as MIM schema based ISO 10303-21 file.
The Domain Model defined in ISO 10303-3001 provides mechanisms to reference files containing MIM schema based ISO 10303-21 data ("External file reference"). It provides further a mechanism to reference data inside the other file ("External element reference").

description.p: If the implementation method is ISO 10303-21, the file format shall be encoded according to the syntax and EXPRESS language mapping defined in ISO 10303-21 and to the MIM schema referenced in of this part of ISO 10303.

annex_clause.title: Introduction
annex_clause.p: This annex provides a brief overview of the new STEP Architecture in development at ISO/TC 184/SC 4. Complete description of the new STEP architecture is available in the standing document N3210 STEPlib : Requirements and high level specifications for the STEP Extended Architecture.
This DIS has been produced with the Extended STEP architecture method and is intended to serve as a comment collation object to enhance the Extended STEP architecture proposal.

As shown in the Figure H1, the way for building Application Protocols in STEP have been continuously evolving in order to improve the processes for their production and usage, and in order including new mainstream technologies, being for document production (STEP modules which allow to build an AP as a composite XML document) or data exchange (binding with XML for Web oriented use cases). The “Old STEP” architecture is the first one. It describes monolithic APs, from a set of Integrated Resources (generic – part4x to 99- and application – part 1xx) . The main drawback was the difficulty for AP project team to produce consistent mappings with the integrated resources and ensuring the definition of a single integrated model and no easy way to reuse what was done by other application protocols producing a set of independent diverging implemented schemas. It is the reason why this architecture was replaced by the Modular STEP architecture which is the current one. The STEP modular architecture objectives are to promote integration by reuse of common AP modules, allowing reuse of module schemas by aggregation but also reuse of module document description. The aim was to speed up development and publication. A new family of parts appears for describing the modules, the Application Interpreted Constructs (Part 5xx).

OASIS’s PLCS “version 1” was based on DEXlib, coming from new business needs on lifecycle, requests for XSD/XML implementation method. It introduced a higher level development framework with inputs from semantic web, based on the modular architecture. Based on Part28 default binding applied to the ARM model, the implementation appeared at that time inefficient. Underlying concepts of the PLCS framework are aligned with the STEP philosophy. Based on this experience, OASIS’s PLCS “version 2” is based on PLCSlib, which was not fully mapped to the underlying STEP modules. In PLCSlib, the PSM is the integration layer from which implementation are derived from the Express PSM model. This integration layer serves as a basis for the development of DEXes with a SysML framework.

AP242 Edition 1 BO Model’s requirements are closed to PLCS concerning the implementation method, which is based on XML Schema and XML. But even with the strong requirement for full integration to the modular architecture, it failed to provide complete mapping from BO Model to ARM Modules. In order to provide cross life cycle interoperability, an harmonization effort has started between BO Model and PSM, both being an implementation layer with the same targeted implementation method.

Today’s goal of the Extended STEP architecture is to ensure consistency and integration on the whole stack and across AP. The associated methodology is model based and allows extensions from other domains and technologies.

tech_disc.annex_clause:
The introduction of the Extended STEP Architecture provides new capabilities in the development, documentation, testing and implementation of an application protocol.
The Extended STEP architecture is based on a multi-layer information model spanning from the Application Activity Model to the ARM.
Figure H.2.1 gives the details of the Extended STEP Architecture approach.
STEP Architecture Extensions
Implementation forms stepmod + steplib after extension 2
The STEP Extended Architecture extension 1 stack is composed of the following models
Activity model;
Conceptual model;
Domain model;
ARM;
AIM. Extension 2 of the Extended Architecture will include a Core Model as described in Annex B of the standing document N3210 STEPlib. The AIM, and the Integrated Resources are the initial integration models shared by all the STEP Application Protocols.
The Activity model, the Conceptual model, the Domain model and the ARM are specific to each Application Protocol. Some sub-elements of these models can be shared by multiple APs.
All the models, from the Conceptual model to the AIM, are formally mapped with each others.
All the mappings between the conceptual model, domain model, core model and ARM in SysML are realized using SysML parametric diagrams.
The SysML model is a complete integrated model divided in UML packages and sub-packages. The packages are defined as follow:
The AP package (one package per AP) with:
an activity model package,
a conceptual model package,
a domain model package.
The ARM in SysML package.
The detailed description of the models and their mappings are described in the standing document N3210 STEPlib.
The application protocol domain model defines the business objects and allow constrains or specific usage of the core model for a specific industrial application and particular segments of the product lifecycle.
In order to facilitate the model through the various diagrams, each model in the stack is assigned a specific color.

The documentation structure contains 2 main branches under the main AP document:
The usual AP Module documentation with the ARM and AIM definitions, and access to the whole modules library needed to implement the application protocol in Express.
The new domain model documentation with the domain model, normative XSD and mappings between the domain and the ARM.
Documentation Scheme for publishing AP242 ed2 DIS

AP 242 has the following two implementation forms:
Part 21 files conform to the AP 242 MIM Longform schema
XML files conform to the AP 242 Domain Model derived XML Schema
The relationship between the two implementation forms is explicitly provided in AP 242 by the mapping specification (ARM to MIM, clause 5.1), the mapping from the SysML Model to the SysML AP 242 ARM, and the XML configuration specification (SysML to XML schema,new annex in AP 242). On this basis implementations can be realized to convert AP 242 Part 21 files into XML files and vice versa.
As AP 242 allows for both MIM Longform and XML implementations on the Domain Model level, recommendations and rules are required, when which implementation form should be used, such as the ARM for composite materials. Such recommendations are defined outside of this standard in dedicated AP 242 Recommended Practices. AP242 recommended practices are available:
For the CAD domain, CAx-IF recommended practices
For the PDM domain, PDM-IF recommended practices
AP 242 describes the implementation technology without ambiguity. Example: the standard contains both the Domain model XML schema and the XML transformation specification.
